content: On Friday, Entergy (ETR) got an upgrade to its Relative Strength (RS) Rating, from 70 to 73. X IBD's proprietary rating measures market leadership with a 1 (worst) to 99 (best) score. The rating shows how a stock's price performance over the last 52 weeks holds up against all the other stocks in our database. Over 100 years of market history shows that the best stocks tend to have an 80 or better RS Rating as they launch their biggest price moves. See if Entergy can continue to show renewed price strength and hit that benchmark. See How IBD Helps You Make More In StocksEntergy has moved more than 5% past a 78.00 entry in a first-stage double bottom, meaning it's now out of a proper buy range. Look for the stock to offer a new chance to pick up shares like a three-weeks tight or pullback to the 50-day or 10-week moving average. Top and bottom line growth moved higher last quarter. Earnings were up 0%, compared to -27% in the prior report. Revenue increased from -1% to 6%. The company is expected to report its latest results on or around Oct. 25.Entergy holds the No. 10 rank among its peers in the Utility-Electric Power industry group. Edenor (EDN), Pampa Energia (PAM) and Nextera Energy (NEE) are among the top 5 highly rated stocks within the group.RELATED:IBD Stock Rating Upgrades: Rising Relative StrengthWhy Should You Use IBD's Relative Strength Rating?How Relative Strength Line Can Help You Judge A Stock

Idacorp (IDA) had its Relative Strength (RS) Rating upgraded from 67 to 71 Friday -- a welcome improvement, but still shy of the 80 or higher score you prefer to see. X IBD's proprietary RS Rating identifies technical performance by showing how a stock's price action over the last 52 weeks compares to that of the other stocks in our database. Decades of market research reveals that the stocks that go on to make the biggest gains typically have an RS Rating of at least 80 in the early stages of their moves. See if Idacorp can continue to rebound and clear that threshold. Idacorp is trying to complete a flat base with a 90.77 entry. See if it can clear the breakout price in heavy volume. Idacorp showed -12% EPS growth in its most recent report. Sales increased 6%. The company earns the No. 8 rank among its peers in the Utility-Electric Power industry group. PNM Resources (PNM), Edenor (EDN) and Nextera Energy (NEE) are among the top 5 highly rated stocks within the group.RELATED:Which Stocks Are Showing Rising Relative Strength?Why Should You Use IBD's Relative Strength Rating?How Relative Strength Line Can Help You Judge A Stock

Eversource Energy (ES) had its Relative Strength (RS) Rating upgraded from 63 to 74 Friday -- a welcome improvement, but still shy of the 80 or better score you prefer to see. X This exclusive rating from Investor's Business Daily tracks price performance with a 1 (worst) to 99 (best) score. The score shows how a stock's price performance over the last 52 weeks compares to all the other stocks in our database. Decades of market research reveals that the best-performing stocks tend to have an RS Rating north of 80 as they launch their biggest runs. See if Eversource Energy can continue to show renewed price strength and hit that benchmark. The stock is building a flat base with a 63.44 entry. See if the stock can clear the breakout price in heavy volume. Earnings growth rose last quarter from 6% to 13%. But sales fell from 2% to 0%. Eversource Energy earns the No. 9 rank among its peers in the Utility-Electric Power industry group. PNM Resources (PNM), Edenor (EDN) and Nextera Energy (NEE) are among the top 5 highly rated stocks within the group.RELATED:Stocks With Rising Relative Strength RatingsWhy Should You Use IBD's Relative Strength Rating?How Relative Strength Line Can Help You Judge A Stock

If you like "The Odd Couple," May was your kind of market. A mix of technology stocks and defensive sectors outperformed. The tech stocks were driven by secular themes that seem able to keep growing even if the overall economy's growth is tepid.The S&P 500 gained 1.41% last month while U.S. diversified stock mutual funds inched ahead by a more modest 0.38%. Global science/technology funds and science-technology funds led sectors, advancing 5.88% on average and 4.69% respectively.Other leading sectors were more defensive. Utility funds gained 3.43% and international real estate funds tacked on 3.12%. Consumer goods funds also did well, growing 2.00%."The technology sector did well because of across-the-board interest in cell phones, mobile devices and software," said Bernie Horn, a manager of $431.8 million Polaris Global Value Fund (PGVFX), an IBD Best Mutual Fund Awards winner, having outperformed the MSCI EAFE over the past one, three, five and 10 years that ended Dec. 31.Some cloud computing leaders also added to tech's showing. Microsoft (MSFT) and Amazon.com (AMZN) posted gains. "They are growing their cloud services dramatically," said David Chalupnik, head of equities for Nuveen Asset Management.IBD'S TAKE: Amazon has a solid 97 Composite Rating. It posted a 32.1% earnings surprise last quarter. See how its additional easy-to-understand fundamental and technical data stack up against rivals' at IBD's Stock Checkup.Defensive sectors also did well as investors sought safety amid doubts about the strength of economic growth. "The market was having a debate," Chalupnik said. "Investors aren't sure which way the economy is headed. The economic numbers that (came out) in May were mixed. The employment number was OK, but retail sales were a little light. The CPI (inflation rate) number was low for the second month in a row." That last item is a sign that the U.S. economy is not heating up very fast.Precious metals funds, a defensive group, inched up 0.34% due to investor jitters over Washington, D.C., Horn said. "The weekly hysteria over Trump comments regarding Russia tends to make some people think that the Federal Reserve may not be able to increase rates as expected," he said. "That puts monetary policy into flux, which usually drives money into precious metals."Large-cap growth funds gained 2.87%, leading U.S. diversified stock mutual fund categories.World equity funds easily topped U.S. stock funds with a 2.92% gain.Taxable bond funds inched up 0.64% on average. Tax-exempt funds tacked on 1.20%.Going forward, Horn expects stock markets to benefit from improving economic growth and diminished political drama. "Notwithstanding political volatility around the world, underlying economic growth is slowly increasing," Horn said. "And there's less of the uncertainty that was holding back individual and corporate spending. The U.S. elections, Brexit (the initial decision), the French election — all are in the past. The U.S. market has seen valuations rise. But outside the U.S., there are lots of great values."Magna International (MGA), a Canada-based maker of car and truck parts, is one such name he likes. "In an environment where competition among parts suppliers has been reduced, surviving companies like this are well-positioned to provide components whether the world goes electric or not," he said.And he still sees U.S. stocks that he likes. "Quest Diagnostic (DGX) is the largest provider of medical tests in the country," Horn said. "They're doing a better job of creating efficiencies in their operations, keeping costs in line."He also likes NextEra Energy (NEE). "It's one of the best-run utilities in the country if not the world, with a strong presence in clean fuels like natural gas and wind and solar to a lesser extent. It's not the cheapest stock, but management makes continuous improvements in their cost structure."Horn also expects health insurers and managed care providers Anthem (ANTM) and UnitedHealth Group (UNH) to benefit from the reduction of regulatory burdens of any arrangement that replaces or reforms ObamaCare.Chalupnik sees potential for better growth from key foreign markets than the U.S. Europe, China, Japan and emerging markets are growing at decent rates, he says. "The whole global economy is growing together," he said. "It's the first time since 2010 that you could say that."His team has overweights in materials and industrials relative to the S&P 500, although it has trimmed its overweights. It has held its energy weighting steady.Detroit Edison (DTE) illustrates his appetite for energy. "People and businesses still need electricity," he said. "It is a very well run utility. It has good management, a good regulatory environment. It delivers quarter-in, quarter-out." In addition, the stock has a 3% dividend yield.He also likes Wal-Mart Stores (WMT). "It's a very stable company, probably the next big growth company out there. It's one of the few retailers that's growing same-store sales. And its e-commerce business is tremendous. And it's trading at an attractive multiple."Share price is up 15% so far this year, including a 5% gain in May. But the stock has a weak 59 Composite Rating from IBD, on a scale from 1 to 99.Douglas Burtnick, a manager of $1.8 billion Aberdeen U.S. Small Cap Equity (GSXIX), an IBD Best Mutual Funds Award winner for topping the S&P 500 over one, three, five and 10 years, likes Ellie Mae (ELLI). "They sell software and services to banks, which help them create more efficiency around the mortgage origination process," he said.Ellie Mae's systems are helping to transform what has been a paper-oriented industry into a digitally focused one. "That makes the process faster and easier," Burtnick said. "Banks are willing to pay for that efficiency."And Chalupnick likes the outlook for Lamb Weston (LW), a producer and distributor of frozen foods that was spun out of ConAgra (CAG) late last year. "It is a relatively new company, and it is under-followed," he said. "They are one of the few packaged-goods food companies that is growing its unit volume. General Mills unit volume is down (in its North American retail segment)."RELATED:Mutual Fund Managers Look For Winners In Industrials, Materials, Tech, BanksThe Painless Way To Add $140,000 To Your Retirement Account

Florida-based utility NextEra Energy (NEE) continues being a dependable dividend stock and made its customary annual increase last month. The company raised the quarterly dividend to 98.25 cents a share from 87 cents. The dividend made the annualized yield 3%. NextEra said the increase was part of a plan announced in 2015 for 12% to 14% annual growth in dividends…

Major stock-index ETFs were lower near midday Friday, led lower by financials and energy sectors. Utilities and gold showed strength as investors favored defensive areas.SPDR S&P 500 (SPY), PowerShares QQQ (QQQ) and SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA) were all off 0.2% at midday.Utilities Select Sector SPDR (XLU) was up 1.1%. Top holdings NextEra Energy (NEE) was up 0.8% and yielding 3.0%, Duke Energy (DUK) jumped 1.3% and was yielding 4.2%, and Southern Co. (SO) was up 1.6% and yielding 4.5%.SPDR Gold Shares (GLD) rose 0.7%, advancing for the fourth straight session and heading for its fourth straight weekly gain. The ETF, whose holdings are physical gold, has rallied 12% from its Dec. 15 low and sits 8% below its 52-week high.VanEck Vectors Gold Miners (GDX) was up 0.5%. The ETF, which tracks gold mining stocks, has rallied 31% from its December low but still sits 23% below its 52-week high.Select Sector Financials (XLF) fell 0.9%. Top holdings JPMorgan Chase (JPM) was off 1.2%. Also down were Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) by 0.3%, Wells Fargo (WFC) by 1.7%, Bank of America[ticker symb=BAC] by 1.5%, Citigroup (C) by 1.7% and Goldman Sachs (GS) by 1.7%.The ETF is up 5% this year and 25% since the November election.Here's a look at the performance of major exchange traded funds across key asset classes on the stock market today.The Relative Price Strength (RS) Rating measures a stock's price performance over the last 12 months vs. all stocks and ETFs, on a scale of 1 to a best-possible 99.SPDR S&P 500 (SPY), -0.2%, RS 56PowerShares QQQ (QQQ), -0.2%, RS 67SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA), -0.2, RS 64IShares Core S&P Mid-Cap (IJH), -0.2%, RS 64IShares Russell 2000 (IWM), -0.5%, RS 69IShares MSCI EAFE (EFA), -0.9%, RS 43Vanguard FTSE Emerging Markets (VWO),-1.1%, RS 64SPDR Gold Shares (GLD), +0.7%, RS 28United States Oil (USO), -0.6%, RS 53IShares Core U.S. Aggregate Bond (AGG), +0.4%, RS 23PowerShares DB U.S.$ Bullish (UUP), 0%, RS 33IPath S&P 500 VIX Short-Term Futures (VXX), +1.3%, RS 1RELATED:What's The Stock Market Doing Now?Can Oil & Gas Equipment ETF Have Another Strong Year?3 Best ETFs To Make Bullish Bet On U.S. Growth With 'Trump Trades'

(In)Justice: We all know about President Obama's commutation of the 35-year sentence of traitor Chelsea Manning, nee Bradley, who handed U.S. secrets over to WikiLeaks, leading to the deaths of an untold number of people. That was bad enough.But even worse, but sadly less publicized, was Obama's decision to pardon Oscar Lopez Rivera, the terrorist whose FALN planted more than 130 bombs across America during the 1970s and 1980s, supposedly on behalf of Puerto Rican independence.Lopez Rivera was sentenced to 55 years in prison for seditious conspiracy and a number of weapons charges. He's served 35 years of that original sentence.What did he and the group he led actually do? As we noted, his group went on a two-decade bombing spree that led to the deaths of at least six and the wounding and maiming of many more. The worst attack came in 1975, when the FALN bombed the Fraunces Tavern, killing four and wounding more than 50 others.His supporters on the left, who always seem to make excuses for terrorists masquerading as Latin American "revolutionaries," think he's served long enough. Lopez Rivera is 74, and has been in prison nearly half his life. He should be let out, they say.No he shouldn't.To begin with, in order for a lengthy sentence for such heinous crimes to have the desired deterrent effect, the entire sentence needs to be served — not reduced.It would be one thing if Lopez Rivera were repentant. But he isn't. Not a bit.He's been offered official chances to say he's sorry, to ask for forgiveness from those he harmed, but has refused. And he tried to escape twice, conspiring with others in one of the escape attempts to acquire explosives, grenades, guns and armor-piercing bullets. The threat was considered so severe that the court added 15 years to his original sentence. Sound repentant?Those who justify what Lopez Rivera did by calling him a "freedom fighter" or other such insulting nonsense are despicable. Yet, shamelessly, his far-left supporters lit up Twitter with their celebrations on Wednesday.Immediately after the news hit, New York's far-left Mayor Bill DeBlasio tweeted out: "Thank you @#POTUS for freeing #OscarLopezRivera.""Hamilton" impresario Lin-Manuel Miranda tweeted, "It'll be my honor to play Hamilton the night he goes."Meanwhile, DeBlasio's political ally, New York City Council Speaker Melissa Mark-Viverito, who has long pushed for Lopez Rivera's release, likewise celebrated. "#LaMarqueta was the place to be to celebrate @POTUS decision to free #OscarLopezRivera! Gracias @marquetaretona!"Meanwhile, in Chicago, President Obama's political ally and friend Bill Ayers, paying tribute to a fellow terrorist, tweeted his own salute: "Oscar Lopez freed! Chelsea Manning out!!! Great news! Joy and Justice! Free Leonard (Peltier)! Pardon Ethel (Rosenberg)! Keep rolling!"Oh, you say, but it's only extremists who laud this terrorist murderer? Guess again. Then-President Bill Clinton in 1999 let many of the FALN members walk from prison and wanted to pardon Lopez Rivera, too, but he refused to renounce terrorism.In Congress, Rep. Luis Gutierrez, D-Ill., has for years lobbied hard to free Lopez Rivera. And, perhaps not surprisingly, serial-terrorist-dupe and former U.S. President Jimmy Carter has joined the cause.The media are no better. CBS News in Chicago, the city where Lopez Rivera was arrested after having been found with six pounds of dynamite and blasting caps in his apartment, called him an "activist" in a web headline. NPR referred to Lopez Rivera in a headline as a "Prisoner Who Fought For Puerto Rican Independence."He bombed innocent men, women and children. He killed some, maimed others. That's not a "fighter." That's a coward.What never gets mentioned, however, is that Puerto Rico can be independent anytime it wants. Since 1966, the island commonwealth has held several votes on the issue. And independence has never won. Far from wanting independence, since a 2012 referendum most Puerto Ricans have favored statehood.The truth is, Lopez Rivera and his far-left followers were a group of Castro-wannabes, pursuing a Marxist revolution in Puerto Rico by bombing someone else's country and pretending to "free" people who didn't really want to be freed by them. They weren't freedom fighters, but rather extreme leftists who, if left to their own devices, would have offered Puerto Ricans the same form of state-imposed slavery that the Cubans still live under.They all deserved to serve their full terms in prison, but especially the remorseless Lopez Rivera. That he now gets out will only serve as an incentive to other terrorists. Please remember that the next time we have a domestic attack here in the U.S. Actions have consequences.By refusing to fight terrorism here at home, Obama has shown he doesn't care much about endangering American lives. Perhaps in that context, his release of unrepentant terrorist Oscar Lopez Rivera shouldn't be surprising at all.RELATED:How Left's 'Terrorism' Narrative Threatens Americans' SecurityObama Funded Terrorism With His $1.7 Bil Ransom To IranThe Left's Dangerous Denial About Radical IslamWill Terrorist Attacks Be The New Normal?

Loose wiring or faulty circuit can call for emergency repairs to your home electrical system. Right now, the chart action of utility funds is signaling the need for some immediate attention too."Defensive sectors like utilities and telecom did pretty well earlier this year, but of late, investors have been warming up to higher growth sectors, technology in particular," said Neena Mishra, director of ETF research for Zacks Investment Research. She thinks stretched valuations in defensive sectors may be driving investors toward others that don't look too pricey too.Utility Select Sector SPDR (XLU) lost hundreds of millions in net outflow in each month of the third quarter, though it has grown assets this year to $7.31 billion.This bellwether exchange traded fund offers exposure to 28 electric and gas utilities as well as diversified power companies in the S&P 500. Its top holdings include NextEra Energy (NEE), Duke Energy (DUK) and Southern Co. (SO). It yields 3.27%.XLU vaulted 15.5% in the first quarter amid investors' quest for safety and income. By comparison, SPDR S&P 500 (SPY), a proxy for the broad U.S. market, trudged up 1.4% in the same period.Now this utility ETF sits 10% below the early July high of 53.02 after losing support at key levels of short-term and long-term support over the past six trading sessions. Treasury yields jumped Tuesday on growing expectations of a Federal Reserve rate hike later this year. That makes dividend-paying utilities relatively less attractive.Ari Wald, a senior technical analyst at Oppenheimer & Co., believes utilities could continue to be at risk. If the S&P continues its long-term advance, more cyclical sectors are likely to be rewarded.His firm downgraded the utility sector to underweight in August.IBD'S TAKE: Gold and rate-sensitive equity sectors have come under pressure as the outlook for the next Federal Reserve rate hike remains murky.Despite XLU's recent woes, or perhaps because of it, Wald thinks it has become tactically attractive. He finds the ETF is increasingly oversold and due for a bounce."A rally back above the ETF's 200-day moving average at $48.50 would be an encouraging start," Wald told IBD on Monday. On the stock market today, XLU fell a further 2.1% to 47.29 -- its lowest level since April.Sector rotations are the hallmark of a healthy bull market, Wald added, because "no sector becomes so extended to the upside or the downside to derail the market's broader advance."Mishra sees another reason that utilities could be in favor again. She expects more volatility in the coming weeks as the presidential election approaches and the earnings season picks up pace. With the markets pricing in a Clinton victory, a tighter race and potential Trump win could trigger a broad market sell-off."In such a scenario, I wouldn't be surprised to see some money moving back into defensive sectors until there is better visibility for the market," Mishra said.But she's not expecting a utilities rally like the one earlier this year, and she's bearish on the sector in the longer term.The Fed's latest signals have upped the odds of a hike in interest rates in December, she pointed out. Yield-bearing equity sectors, such as utilities and REITs, sell off when rates are rising.RELATED:Gold ETF Tumbles To Its Lowest Level Since Brexit Vote

With growth stocks in favor, you'd think that high-yielding areas of the market would be going out of favor, but that's not entirely the case as several Utility Leaders are setting up for potential moves higher. Another is still in buying range.Utilities lagged Tuesday but have generally been acting well after Wall Street perceived the Fed to be more dovish than hawkish at the conclusion of last week's meeting.The Fed, as expected, left the federal funds rate unchanged, while longer-term rate projections showed a slower pace of increases. Policymakers now expect three rate hikes through the end of 2017, down from five at their June meeting.The Sept. 21 policy statement fueled a nice rally in interest-rate-sensitive utility stocks. SPDR Utility (XLU) jumped 2% in strong volume. However, on Tuesday, the popular ETF reversed off intraday highs, falling 1.3%, and sinking back below its 50-day moving average near 50.51.Consolidated Edison (ED) reclaimed its 10-week moving average last week as it works on a flat base with an 81.98 entry. It had the highest Accumulation/Distribution Rating in Tuesday's screen at A-. The rating, on a scale of A+ to E, is used to measure institutional buying and selling in a stock over the past three months. A+ signifies heavy institutional buy; E means heavy institutional selling.Consolidated Edison has paid a dividend of 67 cents a share for three straight quarters. It currently yields 3.4%.On a day when the Utility-Electric Power group fell around 1%, NextEra Energy (NEE) bucked the trend, rising 0.4%. It's also working on a flat base with a 132.08 buy point.NextEra pays a quarterly dividend of 87 cents a share, giving it an annualized yield of 2.8%.While many utilities are building bases, AES Corp. (AES) is in a slightly different boat because it's still in buy range after a breakout over a 12.82 buy point.The Virginia-based firm is another electric utility that pays a quarterly dividend of 11 cents a share, good for an annualized yield of 3.4% -- much better than the S&P 500's current yield of 2.07% as of Monday's market close.

Investors could toast the third quarter, the strongest of the year, but September alone was about as exciting as a bottle of bubbly that gone's flat.In the third quarter, the S&P 500 rose 3.85%, lifting U.S. diversified stock mutual funds by 4.8% on average. The broad market advanced despite barely breaking even in September, nosing upward a modest 0.02%. Stock funds edged ahead a mere 0.22% last month.That raised stock funds to a 6.38% gain year to date.The stock market's start-and-stop motion in the third quarter has prompted many fund managers to plan ahead by sticking with names driven by strong trends, such as the shift to cloud computing, and with companies that seem capable of grinding out growth no matter how blah growth may be in the broader economy.Click Here To See A List Of IBD Mutual Fund Quarterly Leaders"The first half of the year saw more of a defensive-led rally," said Lew Piantedosi, a manager of seven Eaton Vance funds with $3.8 billion in total assets. "But in Q3 that reversed. Cyclicals like tech and industrials did better."Click Here To See A List Of Mutual Fund Six-Month LeadersWorld equity funds advanced 6.42% in Q3, outperforming U.S. diversified stock funds. Last month, world equity funds rose 1.33%. China regional funds, which gained 11.36%, led the world equity market. In September they racked up a 2.39% return.If cyclical sectors stay hot, then stocks tied to transportation of industrial goods and commodities could continue their third-quarter gains. Piantedosi held Norfolk Southern (NSC), which gained 14% in the third quarter, in his Focused Growth Opportunities Class I (EIFGX) as of July 31.His Tax-Managed Growth 1.1 (EITMX) held Union Pacific (UNP), which rolled to a 12% gain.But what if most cyclicals lose their head of steam? Piantedosi prefers the long view."I focus on big-picture growth trends that are sustainable despite shifting macro noise," he said.Facebook (FB), Amazon (AMZN) and Alphabet (GOOGL) are sustainable growers."They benefit from great secular tailwinds," he said. "While those names have done well — especially Amazon — there's still a runway for them."IBD'S TAKE: IBD's Brian Deagon analyzes the tailwinds driving Amazon. In the "Buys & Sells" column, Julie Mak points out that some leading mutual funds have been selling Alphabet and Amazon.Another plus for the tech sector is that acquisitions seem to be picking up, he says.Click Here To See A List Of Mutual Fund Category PerformancePiantedosi says investors should brace for volatility until the elections. A Democratic White House, with the Senate and House in Republican hands would mean continued gridlock, he says. Still, his impression is that support for tax reform is growing in both parties. "That would be a huge positive," he said.In health care, he's wary of many drugmakers due to political calls for price regulation. Still, he likes Celgene (CELG), Vertex (VRTX) and Biogen (BIIB)."Biotechs feel a little safer (than non-biotech drugmakers)," he said. "They are doing wonderful things to cure big diseases. They combine positive reward-to-risk. And they're beaten up and trading at valuations at attractive valuations."Within retail, he likes a few names."It's an area to watch as we head into the holidays, especially some more apparel-oriented stocks," Piantedosi said. "This is a short-term theme."Macy's (M) has gone through markdowns after having to discount last year's overstock, he says. The mild winter dampened consumer demand for warm clothes. And competition is stiff from Amazon."The company has done a great job managing inventories going into the holidays this year," Piantedosi said. "Expectations are low. And they've been monetizing real estate" by selling or closing unneeded locations.And he continues to like home-improvement giants Lowe's (LOW) and Home Depot (HD)."Housing is still strong," he said. "Interest rates are still low. Consumers are OK. And (stock) prices have come in a little over fears of a housing slowdown."Jeff Rottinghaus, T. Rowe Price manager of $1.6 billion Growth & Income (PRGIX) and of $314.1 million U.S. Large-Cap Core (TRULX), says stock prices in general seem fairly priced. But he likes some names in health care, where prices have been pushed down.He calls Becton Dickinson (BDX), Medtronics (MDT) and UnitedHealth Group (UNH) "quiet" because none is under political pressure over drug pricing. Becton develops medical supplies, Medtronic develops implantable cardiac devices and other products and UnitedHealth is the industry's biggest managed-care provider.Yet Rottinghaus is shopping among biotechs because prices are so beaten down.He is underweight in the tech sector. But he likes companies benefiting from the secular trend of cloud computing's growth. Those include Alphabet and Microsoft (MSFT). He also likes the sustainable secular growth of Visa (V) and Facebook.Rottinghaus also likes NextEra Energy (NEE), which has a 2.9% dividend yield."It's the largest renewable-energy generator in the U.S.," he said. "Its dividend yield is roughly 3%. But we wouldn't own it without the low-double-digit earnings growth we expect from them."Growth-oriented sectors led stock funds' third-quarter charge. Science-technology funds zoomed ahead 13.21% for the quarter on top of a 2.89% September gain.Health-biotechnology funds were also strong, manufacturing gains of 6.84% and 5.83% in the quarter.Small-cap growth funds gained 8.19% on average, leading all U.S. diversified stock fund categories. That left them up 6.84% for the year. Their September gain was 1.16%. RELATED:Stock Fund Managers Seek Scarce Profits In Durable-Growth StocksMarket Treaded Water In August As Investors Shifted To Growth Stocks

Major ETFs were trading higher midday Monday, led by the real estate, utilities and financial sectors. Japan ETFs also pushed higher.Talk of an interest rate hike has been lifting financials, with bank stocks in particular on the rise.IShares U.S. Real Estate (IYR), with $5.07 billion in assets, was up 0.7% Monday. Real Estate Select Sector SPDR (XLRE), with $114.11 million in assets, was up 1%. Both ETFs have the same top five holdings, though at different weightings. Simon Property (SPG) and American Tower (AMT) were each up as much as 0.8% Monday, but Public Storage (PSA) was slightly lower. Crown Castle (CCI) was up 0.5%, and Prologis (PLD) was higher by more than 1%.IYR is trading above its 200-day moving average but is just below its 50-day line. Prologis is the only top holding still finding technical support above its 50-day line. It's yielding 3.2% and has a Relative Price Strength Rating of 86.IBD'S TAKE: ETFs often put the most assets in the biggest companies that they track, but the biggest aren't always the strongest performers at any given moment. To find the highest rated stocks in an ETF, check how they stack up in Stock Checkup.SPDR Utilities (XLU), with $7.3 billion in assets, was up 0.7%. Among the top holdings, NextEra Energy (NEE), at a 9% weighting, was up 0.4% with a dividend yield 2.9%. Duke Energy (DUK), yielding 4.3%; Southern (SO), yielding 4.4%; Dominion Resources (D), yielding 3.7%; and American Electric Power (AEP), yielding 3.4%, were each up 0.6% or less.All are trading above their 200-day moving averages but below their 50-day lines. NextEra has the highest RS Rating, at 69%.SPDR Financial (XLF) was up 1% and trading at its highest level since December. The $15.7 billion ETF counts Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB), JPMorgan Chase (JPM), Wells Fargo (WFC), Bank of America (BAC) and Citigroup (C) as its top holdings.Berkshire, JPMorgan, Bank of America and Citi all remain in uptrends, trading above their 50-day and 200-day moving averages. The 200-day lines of Bank of America and Citi are situated under their 50-day lines. Wells Fargo's 2% rally puts it just under its 200-day line.Financial Services Select Sector SPDR (XLFS), was up 1.1%. It has the same top-five holdings as XLF, but with slightly higher weightings. That reflects the absence of real estate in the XLFS.SDPR Materials (XLB) was also up 1.1%IShares MSCI Japan (EWJ) rose 0.3%, while iShares Currency Hedged MSCI Japan (HEWJ) climbed 0.8%.Of other currency-hedged Japan funds, WisdomTree Japan Hedged (DXJ) advanced 1.1%, and Deutsche X-trackers MSCI Japan Hedged Equity (DBJP) gained 0.8%.The dollar continued higher, with PowerShares DB US $ Bullish (UUP) up 0.2% after leaping 0.7% Friday. The ETF, which tracks the dollar against a basket of other major currencies, is testing resistance at its 50-day line.Talk of a rise in U.S. interest rates tends to buoy the dollar and help currency-hedged ETFs.Gold prices were nearly flat Monday. SPDR Gold Trust (GLD), which tracks the price of bullion, was up 0.2%. VanEck Vectors Gold Miners (GDX), was up 0.3%.Here's how major exchange traded funds across major asset classes performed today, with IBD Relative Price Strength Ratings.The RS Rating is a measure of a stock's price performance over the last 12 months, compared with all stocks and ETFs, on a scale of 1 to a best-possible 99.Following daily ETF market action can be key to successful investing:SPDR S&P 500 (SPY), +0.4%, RS 52PowerShares QQQ (QQQ), +0.1%, RS 60SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA), +0.5%, RS 52IShares Core S&P Mid-Cap (IJH), +0.8%, RS 60IShares Russell 2000 (IWM), +0.5%, RS 63IShares MSCI EAFE (EFA), 0%, RS 30Vanguard FTSE Emerging Markets (VWO), +0.4%, RS 73SPDR Gold Shares (GLD), +0.2%, RS 73United States Oil (USO), -1.1%, RS 18IShares Core U.S. Aggregate Bond (AGG), +0.2%, RS 37PowerShares DB U.S.$ Bullish (UUP), +0.3%, RS 25IPath S&P 500 VIX Short-Term Futures (VXX), -1.6%, RS 1RELATED:The First New S&P 500 Sector Since 1999 Is A Big Deal For Investors.

Stocks held onto moderate gains after the Federal Reserve stayed put on short-term interest rates. Fed officials signaled an even-slower rate hike path going forward, but still faster than markets are pricing in.In a statement issued at 2 p.m. ET, the central bank noted that the pace of improvement in the jobs market "has slowed" but also noted strengthening household spending, continued gains in the housing sector, while "the drag from net exports appears to have lessened."The Fed also noted that inflation is still short of its 2% long-term goal while business spending is still "soft."The major indexes are trying to snap a four-day losing streak. Meanwhile, big-cap techs showed mixed action, with Apple (AAPL) rising and Amazon.com (AMZN) letting early gains slip away. But clearly, based on stock chart action, the former is still in trouble and has not yet shown the kind of strong institutional buying that leads to the formation of new solid bases -- the stuff that ushers potential new breakouts to new highs. The latter, meanwhile, continues to be a member of IBD Leaderboard and its long-term uptrend remains firmly intact.The Nasdaq composite, S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average briefly halved their pre-Fed gains, but are all back to 0.4% gains. That's a small fraction of each indexes' respective losses in recent days. The Nasdaq fell as much as 3.3% in the prior four days of trading, yet Tuesday's bounce off the pivotal 200-day moving average encouraged the bulls. The Dow transports gained 0.6% after the Fed news. The Dow utilities are down almost 0.2%.Volume on both major exchanges was still running lower vs. the same time Tuesday, but is likely to pick up into the close.The Fed raised interest rates in December by 25 basis points, the first hike since June 2006, yet has dithered since then on future increases in the cost of money due to worries about slowing growth in China, a poor May jobs report in the U.S. and economic uncertainty in many parts of Europe.From an industry-group perspective, metal ores, steel, coal and other metals-related stocks vied with apparel, fiber optic, jewelry and department store firms at the top of market's upside, while a host of utility shares fell 1% or more. NextEra Energy (NEE) slipped less than 1% to 124.30 in light trade; its rally since a late-January breakout past a 108.34 cup-with-handle base is still solid. It is in buy range from a 119.47 buy point from flat base.Apple edged 0.5% higher to 98.05 in light volume. While from a near-term perspective the iPhone maker has been trading between a band of 90 and 100, keep an eye on the falling 50- and 200-day moving averages. If the stock cannot rebound past these critical levels, it indicates a lack of greed among institutional players. The stock is simply too overly invested at this point to become a market leader like it was in the mid-2000s. As of the end of the first quarter, 4,844 mutual funds owned a stake in Apple, down from 4,922 funds in Q1 2015, according to data from William O'Neil + Co.Apple has a Composite Rating of 28 on a scale of 1 to 99; its 19 Relative Strength rating means it's underperforming 81% of all companies in IBD's stock database over the past 12 months.Among top-performing IBD 50 names in the stock market today, Dave & Buster's (PLAY) cooled off, down 2% to 47.49 in heavy volume. The innovative restaurant and game entertainment chain is still extended from a breakout past a 42.22 entry. It debuted on the Nasdaq at 16 in October 2014.As seen in Tuesday’s Big Picture column and Market Pulse table, the market’s current outlook was downgraded from “confirmed uptrend” to “uptrend under pressure.” This means an investor can still buy stocks that break out from properly formed bases, but the probability of making money is lower, given the increased intensity of professional selling. The Nasdaq composite saw its distribution day count (denoting heavy selling) rise back to 4.Is your stock is best in class within its industry group in terms of profit growth, margins, sales, return on equity, institutional fund sponsorship and relative price strength? Check it out at Investors.com's exclusive tool, IBD Stock Checkup.

When the key stock market gauges fall 3% or more in a single session, many investors know they can expect to see some stocks sink a lot more. As an income investor, what do you want to see in your stocks amid periods of market turmoil, such as the Brexit sell-off Friday? Obviously, a stock that rose on Friday is showing…

Mixed reality is about to get the "Star Wars" treatment. Walt Disney's (DIS) Lucasfilm ILMxLAB and Magic Leap announced a partnership Thursday at a Wired conference, teasing audiences with a mixed-reality video in which R2-D2 and C-3PO appear to be physically present in the room and fervently discussing how to escape a group of stormtroopers.Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google and Qualcomm (QCOM) were early investors in Magic Leap.Virtual reality and mixed reality (the latter layers projections on top of the real world) are still in early days, but legacy media entities clearly aren't hesitating to jump in. Disney also became an investor last year in cinematic VR company Jaunt VR, which consists of several Lucasfilm vets.Meanwhile, Chris Milk, the co-founder of VR startup Within (nee Vrse) announced Thursday — along with the name change — that the company was closing a Series A round of funding led by Andreessen Horowitz. 21st Century Fox (FOXA) also participated.Other notable media money in VR includes Comcast (CMCSA) and Time Warner's (TWX) investment units, which both participated in NextVR's $30.5 million Series A funding round last year.Does this mean that there are more partnership announcements to come? Maybe. VR is already a hot topic in gaming.At E3 2016 this week, virtual reality was a dominant theme. Microsoft (MSFT) teased its VR-capable Project Scorpio console, while Sony (SNE) gave PlayStation VR a formal release date, and Facebook's (FB) Oculus announced the release of 30 full VR games later this year.Shares of Disney finished 0.6% higher on the stock market today. Fox fell 1.1%. Comcast fell 1.2%, and Time Warner slid 1.4%.RELATED:Viacom, Disney, Fox's Real-Life 'Game Of Thrones'Dogs In Race Cars: The Future Of Virtual RealitySony Turns To Batman, 'Star Wars' To Lead Virtual Reality Games

A spate of acquisitions in the utilities sector is helping energy providers fend off rising costs and falling demand, while still providing investors with steady dividend growth. That helps to explain why the sector, often seen as a safe haven in times of trouble, was ranked No. 3 out of 33 on Wednesday. Investors also seem undaunted by the prospect…

With the market back in a confirmed uptrend and Wall Street seemingly getting more comfortable with a Federal Reserve rate hike sooner rather than later, is it time to shun defensive, dividend-paying names in favor of growth? The short answer is that both areas must be respected. Breakouts in the growth space are starting to emerge, but at the same…

Five exchange traded funds in utilities stocks made new highs last week or are near new highs, as the sector emerges as a tempting alternative during the stock market's slump.With some of these ETFs in buy areas on their charts, investors have opportunities to invest in one of the few areas showing solid price action.Utility stocks weakened in April, as bond yields spiked. That was an unwelcome development for utilities because higher rates increase capital costs for an industry that constantly has to spend on plants and equipment. Also, higher bond yields can make utilities' dividends less attractive by comparison.But as Treasury yields started falling, utility ETFs reacted with gains in the past two weeks.The profit outlook for utilities is relatively favorable. The sector's combined profit is expected to drop 2% for the first quarter but rise about 4% for the full year, according to S&P Global Market Intelligence. By both measures, earnings will be well above the S&P's total but below better-performing sectors such as consumer discretionary and health care.The sector's most popular ETF is Utilities Select Sector SPDR (XLU), which trades an average of more than 17 million shares a day. It has climbed back above its 50-day moving average and is near a new high. IShares U.S. Utilities (IDU) has traced a similar chart.Thinly traded PowerShares DWA Utilities Momentum (PUI) broke out of a flat base Wednesday and is in buy range from a 25.63 entry. The fund, which is diversified among various types of utility companies, is based on an index that emphasizes utility stocks showing relative strength, which helps explain its move to new highs.Some of DWA Utilities' top components hit new highs in the past week, including DTE Energy (DTE), WEC Energy (WEC) and American Water Works (AWK). Also, Westar Energy (WR) made a new closing high.Vanguard Utilities (VPU) touched a new high Thursday after finding support around the 50-day moving average. Investors can use that support to purchase shares. But ideally, investors would use the March breakout past a 102.68 buy point to buy the bulk of shares and use the pullback to add a smaller amount.Vanguard Utilities and Fidelity MSCI Utilities (FUTY) are both based on the same index: The MSCI U.S. Investable Market Utilities 25/50 Index.The index is more heavily weighted on Duke Energy (DUK), NextEra Energy (NEE) and Southern Co. (SO), with each representing 6% to 7% of the total fund. In fact, Utilities Select Sector SPDR and iShares U.S. Utilities (based on the Dow Jones U.S. Utilities Index) also have the same companies as top components. NextEra broke out Wednesday but is back below the 119.47 buy point.                   The IBD ETF Leaders index shows the performance of a model portfolio of exchange traded funds that are leading the overall market. The biggest utility ETF cleared its 47.10 buy point decisively Thursday, providing a fresh entry into a defensive sector that has fired investors' imagination this volatile year.Major stock indexes staged a bullish reversal, led by the financial sector, on higher oil prices.SPDR S&P 500 (SPY) and SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA) both poked above their 50-day moving averages for the first time this year.The S&P 500 index, a proxy for the broad market, rose 1% to overcome resistance at the keenly watched 1,950 level.Utilities Select Sector SPDR (XLU) popped 1% on the stock market today, closing at the session high after breaking out of a long consolidation.Volume was below average, however.The ETF invests in energy companies in the S&P 500 index, giving it a large-cap and midcap skew. All but 4 of its 29 stock holdings advanced.Top holding NextEra (NEE) was among the declining stocks. Duke Energy (DUK) and Southern Co. (SO) were among those that advanced.Year to date through Feb. 24, XLU has posted a 10% gain vs. a 4% decline for SPY.The $7.95 billion exchange traded fund has a solid 91 Relative Strength Rating, putting it in the top-performing 9% of all stocks and ETFs tracked by IBD.Its B- Accumulation/Distribution Rating is a sign of solid institutional demand amid stock market volatility.XLU, an elite IBD Leaderboard member, yields 3.5% vs. 2.17% for SPY, offering investors tasty income as well as the potential for capital appreciation.As investors soured on stocks Thursday, gold ETFs rose for a third straight day.SPDR Gold Shares (GLD) is now within 2% of a 120.94 buy point from a cup-with-handle base.Here's a look at how the major exchange traded funds tracking various asset classes performed today.Following daily ETF market action can be key to successful investing:SPDR S&P 500 (SPY), +1.2%, RS 64PowerShares QQQ (QQQ), +1.0%, RS 64SPDR Dow Jones Industrial Average (DIA), +1.3%, RS 64IShares Core S&P Mid-Cap (IJH), +1.1%, RS 54IShares Russell 2000 (IWM), +0.9%, RS 41IShares MSCI EAFE (EFA), +1.2%, RS 44Vanguard FTSE Emerging Markets (VWO), +0.2%, RS 35SPDR Gold Shares (GLD), +0.3%, RS 91IShares Core U.S. Aggregate Bond (AGG), +0.3%, RS 80PowerShares DB U.S.$ Bullish (UUP), -0.1%, RS 75Image provided by Shutterstock.

It was another bad day in the stock market Monday, but a few hearty stocks held up. Utility stocks continue to lead the market.Utility stocks are defensive in nature. Many mutual funds and hedge funds turn to them in hard times on the theory they will decline less than other stocks. Also, a healthy dividend could soften blows to stock price.The two big telcos, Verizon Communications (VZ) and AT&T (T) were holding up with only minor declines in Monday's selling. Right now, Verizon is talking up its plans for a faster 5G network.AT&T was still near a 36.55 buy point of saucer base. But individual investors would do well to think twice during a correction. A money manager might be required to hold stocks or be fully invested. An individual has a big advantage. He or she can ride out a bear market in the safety of cash, and ready to jump in once a new bull market.Once a new uptrend begins, utilities usually underperform.Verizon is in a similar position. A cheery earnings report Jan. 21 kicked off a rally that has brought the stock near a 50.96 buy point from long consolidation.Of the two, Verizon has shown the better growth with a five-year annualized growth rate of 15%. But AT&T has put up decent numbers the past few quarters. Verizon has a 4.4% annualized yield, but AT&T has 5.2%.WEC Energy (WEC) remained above a 53.98 buy point from a cup-with-handle base, and its outperformance over the past few weeks has caused its relative strength line to go nearly vertical, a bullish sign.WEC provides electricity to customers in Wisconsin and Michigan. The stock briefly made a marginal new high Monday, but a falling market pushed it lower.It pays an annualized yield of 3.2%. Its relative strength line is also bolting sharply higher.Southern Co. (SO) is forming the right side of a new base and might now be forming a handle. The company provides electricity states in the South and Southeast. Its annualized yield is 4.5%, although its five-year annualized growth rate is just 4%, south of some of the faster growing utilities.NextEra Energy (NEE) operates in two units. Florida Power & Light provides electricity in Florida, where it's one of the nation's largest regulated electric utilities. NextEra Energy Resources produces wholesale electricity from clean sources, such as natural gas, solar, wind and nuclear.It's extended from 105.95 early entry and also sports a very strong relative strength line. The annualized dividend yield is 2.7% and the five-year annualized growth rate is 6%.

Several of the largest sector and industry ETFs have been mauled by the bear recently.Alerian MLP (AMLP) sits 45% below its 52-week high, putting it firmly in bear market territory. It invests in energy-focused master limited partnerships, typically midstream, pipeline companies.IShares Nasdaq Biotechnology (IBB) is trading 34% off its old high.Then there's Utilities Select Sector SPDR (XLU), a defensively oriented exchange traded fund.Think of it as your bear pepper spray for tough markets. It's worth considering an overweight to utility companies, especially since the broad-market ETF such as SPDR S&P 500 (SPY) that you may already own only has a 3% stake in the sector.XLU has gained 5.7% year to date through Feb. 17 vs. a 5.4% loss for SPY.So far in 2016, AMLP stumbled 18% and IBB tumbled 21%.Meanwhile, XLU hit a new 52-week high of 47 last week as the broad market was sinking. It has a Relative Strength Rating of 85, which means it is outgunning 85% of the stocks and ETFs in the IBD database.That momentum helped it earn a place on the elite IBD Leaderboard, becoming the first ETF to do so.Leaderboard holds stocks with stellar technical and fundamental factors, which offer investors the most potential for the biggest gains. Only three other stocks made that list Thursday -- AT&T (T), Ross Stores (ROST) and Reynolds American (RAI).XLU led these peers with a 2% gain on the stock market today. Along the way, it reclaimed a 46.24 buy point and formed a new handle area with a 47.10 entry. Shares are in a buy range.The $7.62 billion ETF last broke out of a base, on Oct. 24, 2014. Investors who jumped on that opportunity pocketed a 12% gain if they sold when XLU peaked at 49.78 three months later.Keep in mind that while breakouts from sound bases often lead to substantial gains, breakouts can fail. So among wise investors' sell rules are those that will help them cut any losses short.XLU offers broad exposure to 29 high-yielding utility companies in the S&P 500. As such, it has a large- and midcap skew.Top holdings include NextEra Energy (NEE), Duke Energy (DUK) and Southern Co. (SO)The utilities sector is one of the steadiest segments of the market."This fund has been less volatile than the broader market because of the sector's generally stable cash flows and lower sensitivity to economic cycles," Robert Goldsborough, a Morningstar analyst, wrote in a recent report.However, the sector could get hurt if the Fed stays on track with its proposed four interest-rate hikes this year."Higher rates generally make fixed-income instruments more attractive on a relative basis and make bond-like equities, such as utilities companies, less attractive," Goldsborough said.XLU has a 0.14% expense ratio and a 3.5% yield.It's the top-performing utility ETF year to date.

The major averages were holding near their intraday highs late Friday afternoon, but investors remained cautious following a weak GDP report.The Dow Jones industrial average was up 1.8%, the S&P 500 added 1.7%, and the Nasdaq climbed 1.6%. But volume in the stock market today was running below Thursday's levels with about an hour left in the trading session.The economy grew at a 0.7% annual rate in the fourth quarter, below analysts' expectations for a 0.9% gain. The weak reading suggested that the Federal Reserve would move slowly to increase interest rates further, which in turn spurred broad-based stock gains. The Bank of Japan's decision to adopt a negative interest-rate policy also bolstered the market. On the NYSE, advancers were leading decliners by 6 to 1 in late trading.However, there were signs of caution, with the 10-year Treasury yield falling and gold rising as investors sought a safe haven from the market's recent turmoil. Also, defensive stocks such as utilities and food producers continued to fare well.Aqua America (WTR), a Pennsylvania-based provider of water and wastewater services, jumped more than 2%, clearing a 31.19 buy point of a flat base in heavy volume.NextEra Energy (NEE), a Florida-based electricity provider, rose more than 2% to a new high in strong turnover.On Friday, the water and electric utility industry groups were ranked No. 2 and No. 9, respectively, out of the 197 industries tracked by IBD.Facebook (FB) was among few growth stocks that have cleared buy points recently. The IBD Leaderboard stock jumped nearly 3% in double its average daily turnover, breaking out past a 110.75 entry in a new base. The social media giant has soared since it reported strong fourth-quarter profit and revenue growth after Wednesday's market close.Amazon.com (AMZN) didn't fare as well. The Internet retailer plunged 8% after posting weaker-than-expected quarterly results. As a result, the 33-stock Internet retail group sank 5%, making it among only a handful of groups that fell Friday.

A little more than a month ago, only one stock was in IBD's Utility Leaders screen. Today, the list has expanded to about a half dozen and includes the one that never left: NextEra Energy (NEE).In February, NextEra raised its quarterly dividend to $1.11 per share. The increase was part of a goal to boost the cash payout 12% to 14% annually through 2020. The initial target was to continue increases through this year, but the company extended it two years.On an annualized basis, the yield is 2.8%. IBD calculates a healthy long-term annual dividend growth rate of 10%.The stock is in buy range from the 159.74 buy point of a breakout on March 16. NextEra shares have seen little follow-through from that entry, but no sell signal. Compared with other utility stocks, it's a great performance. Most of the sector has been beaten up since November. Even the highest-rated utility stocks remain in price corrections.Expectations of higher bond yields — which compete with utility dividends — are one reason for the underperformance. Unseasonably mild February temperatures hurt electricity demand, too. In a shift, many parts of the U.S. have been unusually cold this month.Trading in NextEra could change sharply Tuesday, when the company reports first-quarter earnings before the market's open. Analysts expect earnings of $1.84 a share, up 5%, according to Thomson Reuters. Sales are expected to rise 5% to $4.16 billion.The company suffered massive losses last year in Hurricane Irma, and management may update those costs in Tuesday's report. In the fourth-quarter report, NextEra said it used savings from the corporate tax cut to offset about $1.3 billion in Hurricane Irma costs. The company said that saved the average customer $250.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseNextEra, which says it's the world's largest utility company, serves about 5 million customers through its Florida Power & Light Co. The NextEra Energy Resources subsidiary combines with affiliates to form the world's largest generator of wind and solar energy. NextEra Energy also has eight nuclear power plants in Florida, New Hampshire, Iowa and Wisconsin.RELATED:Income Investing: Top Dividend Stock Umpqua Boosts Yield, Breaks OutWhen To Sell Stocks: Get Ready For An Exit When The Group's Leaders CrumbleHow To Find The Correct Buy Point When A Stock Breaks Out

Quality, cleanliness and service. Those are core values on which Harry and Esther Snyder built In-N-Out Burger, the regional fast-food chain that counts celebrity chefs Gordon Ramsey and Thomas Keller among its rabid fans.In-N-Out’s star burns even brighter outside the limelight.With annual sales of over $750 million and a per-store average of over $2 million, In-N-Out’s per-store figures beat those of high-profile national chains.In-N-Out started in 1948 as a tiny hamburger stand in the Baldwin Park suburb of Los Angeles.It now boasts 309 locations in California, Nevada, Utah, Texas, Arizona and Oregon.Despite pleas from customers and Wall Street, In-N-Out has resisted an IPO and franchising, preferring a steady expansion that lets it maintain a close watch on each store’s product and execution.It all goes back to quality, cleanliness, service, “the formula that emerged for the standard of running In-N-Out,” wrote Stacy Perman in “In-N-Out Burger: A Behind-the-Counter Look at the Fast-Food Chain That Breaks All the Rules.” “It was not based on some fancy management methodology — rather, it grew out of Harry’s own instincts and exacting personality.”Harry Snyder (1913-76) was born in Vancouver, British Columbia.He had a hard-scrabble upbringing in Seattle and Santa Monica, Calif., often working odd jobs to help support his parents and older sisters in the wake of his father’s usual unemployment.Not one to hit the books, Harry possessed a strong work ethic. He spent his World War II Army deployment in a series of desk jobs due to a perforated ear drum. After the war in 1945, he worked as a caterer at Fort Lawton in Seattle.Esther Snyder (1920-2006), nee Johnson, also grew up in challenging circumstances, as one of eight children in rural Illinois. Unlike Harry, Esther made a college degree a priority.Working part time and taking care of her ill grandmother, she received a teaching certificate and then enrolled in the women’s arm of the Naval Reserve during World War II.After the war, she moved to Seattle, where she finished her bachelor’s degree in zoology from Seattle Pacific University.At 27, she was managing a restaurant in Fort Lawton where she met Harry, 34. Love struck fast, and they married in 1948. Then it was off to Los Angeles to start their new life, also in the food arena.The pair settled in fast-growing Baldwin Park near Los Angeles.While at Fort Lawton, Harry had noticed the increasing popularity of the boxed lunches he delivered. In L.A., he saw the postwar appetite for independence and pleasure and imagined the car becoming a larger aspect of California life.He noticed that Baldwin Park had few restaurants, yet was on a busy route between L.A. and Palm Springs -- a perfect spot for a hamburger stand.The practical Snyders named it In-N-Out to evoke car culture convenience. Harry received $5,000 startup capital from local businessman Charles Noddin and opened the first store in October 1948 on Garvey Avenue, across from the home he shared with Esther.Adding spark to his concept, Harry developed a two-way radio ordering system that let customers get a quick meal without leaving their cars.More than high tech, the high quality of the burgers and fries kept customers coming back.Harry inspected each produce shipment and made sure lettuce was hand-leafed, with tomatoes and onions up to par.Esther formed the day’s patties each morning. At home, she kept a close eye on the books while Harry supervised the stand.Soon, Esther's workload grew with the addition of their two sons, Guy and Rich. Leaving the day-to-day operations to Harry, she continued to do the bookkeeping and always stopped by the store to check in with employees and let them know how important they were to In-N-Out’s burgeoning success.The Snyders' combination of street and book smarts helped create a simple yet exceptional experience. Lines of happy customers around the block became a daily occurrence. After three years, in 1951, In-N-Out opened a second location in nearby Covina.Noddin and Harry soon dissolved the partnership after the former pushed to cut costs by reducing employee pay and using cheaper ingredients. Harry vowed to never again take on outside financing.Harry didn’t dream of putting an In-N-Out on every corner. His goal was to create a sustainable and healthy business to pass on to his sons.He knew a healthy business could be achieved only if his associates felt respected and cared for.From the beginning, Harry and Esther paid associates above minimum wage. Vendors received the same treatment. The Snyders always paid invoices on time.They didn’t cut corners and expected the same treatment from their employees and vendors.If a produce vendor was caught sneaking subpar product into a shipment, Harry ended their relationship on the spot.Employees were so satisfied working at In-N-Out, many didn’t want to leave even though they had plateaued in their positions.Meanwhile, the Snyders continued to expand, in large part to provide professional opportunities to those who helped build the firm.Harry and Esther did so under two conditions: (1) They had to own a building outright. (2) They had to know who would manage it.In-N-Out grew in the 1950s and ’60s with its traditional look and ethos -- perhaps a reassuring presence during huge cultural shifts.“There’s something very appealing about ‘No surprises.’ When you walked in, you knew you were going to be taken care of,” Michael Stern, co-author of “Roadfood,” told IBD.In the mid-1960s, Harry invested in the Irwindale Raceway, a now-defunct drag strip, and had In-N-Out provide event food.After visitors from other parts of the country tasted their first In-N-Out burger at the L.A.-area track, they took glowing reports far and wide. That made the eatery more than a West Coast secret, and requests to franchise grew.In 1976, Harry died at age 63 from lung cancer. In-N-Out had grown to 18 locations in Southern California, and 24-year-old Rich became its new president. The young man was committed to preserving his parents’ commitment to quality, service and cleanliness.With the help of industry mentors and the blessing of Esther, who maintained the position of secretary-treasurer, Rich expanded In-N-Out at a faster clip.In order to grow while maintaining the company’s core values, he came up with two innovations.The first was In-N-Out University, a training facility that opened in 1984. The school taught the management practices that Harry standardized in the early years. Rich “started videotaping employees, and they would review the tapes (during training) to discuss performance, a practice Rich picked up from the NFL,” Perman said.The second was a customer care line, a toll-free phone system staffed by those who had worked at In-N-Out restaurants.During the 1980s, Esther continued her day-to-day involvement in the chain’s operations while increasing philanthropic activities.In 1984, the company began supporting causes to help abused and neglected children, leading to the In-N-Out Burger Foundation.In 1992, In-N-Out opened its first store outside of California — in Las Vegas. But the next year, tragedy struck. Rich died when his plane crashed on the way home from a store opening in Fresno, Calif.Guy, who had worked at In-N-Out but struggled with substance abuse, stepped in as president.By many accounts, Guy demonstrated a talent for updating quality controls. But in 1999, he died from a drug overdose.In-N-Out had grown from those 18 stores when Harry died to a chain of 140 stores in two states.At nearly 80, Esther finally assumed the presidency.She remained the emotional center of the firm, visiting stores and checking on employees regularly.Lynsi Snyder, Guy’s daughter and the only member of the family’s third generation, was only 17 at the time of her father’s death.After high school, she assumed various roles in the company and moved toward the top.After Esther died at age 86, Mark Taylor rose from vice president of operations to the presidency.Then in 2010, Lynsi finally took the helm.The operating procedures instilled by Harry and Esther continue to resonate with customers.In 2015, In-N-Out won Nation’s Restaurant News’ top consumer pick for a limited-service chain for the third year in a row.Meanwhile, Lynsi Snyder-Ellingson is following in her grandparents’ footsteps. The new owner has said she will pass the company to her four children.Built In-N-Out Burger from a hamburger stand to 300-plus location chain.
Overcame: Childhood poverty.
Lesson: Take care of the employees, and they’ll take care of the customers.
“Keep it real simple. Do one thing and do it the best you can,” said Harry Snyder.
Market turmoil has stirred up the Big Cap 20. Back on Dec. 1, the top four names wereFacebook (FB), LinkedIn (LNKD), Salesforce.com (CRM) and Alphabet (GOOGL) — growth stocks all.
They're gone from the list, replaced by defensive names, including food makers, REITs and utilities.

Defensive stocks can shine because messy markets are making money managers mortified. They are being bought on the theory they will go down less than high-flying growth stocks. And, if corporate earnings and the economy are beginning to sag, the public will continue to buy their products and services, while they might reduce their buying of expensive durable goods, such as cars or TV sets.
Defensive stocks also pay dividends that can cushion a downturn.
But investors should keep in mind that a bear market will take everything down with it. There's no such thing as a safe stock.

Among the top names in today's list is Constellation Brands (STZ), a purveyor of beer and booze. Its products could classify it as a defensive stock, but it has definite growth characteristics. It has a five-year annualized growth rate of 25%. Analysts expect 20% growth in fiscal 2016 and 14% growth in 2017.
After riding along the north side of its 50-day moving average for months, it gapped to a new high Thursday after reporting better-than-expected earnings that were 15% higher than a year earlier.
A REIT making this week's cut is Public Storage (PSA).

Public Storage owns 2,200 self-storage facilities with more than 142 million square feet of net rentable space in the U.S. and Europe plus a minority stake in PS Business Parks (PSB), which has another 28 million rentable square feet of commercial and industrial space.
It pays a dividend that is equal to an annualized yield of 2.8%.

Among utilities, WEC Energy Group (WEC), NextEra (NEE) and Dominion (D) made the list. WEC provides electricity and natural gas to 4.4 million customers in Wisconsin, Illinois, Michigan and Minnesota. It operates 70,000 miles of electric lines, 44,000 miles of natural gas pipelines and 8,800 megawatts of power plant capacity.

NextEra transmits electric energy generated by gas, oil, solar, coal, petroleum coke, nuclear and wind, serving 4.7 million customers in the east and lower coasts of Florida. It also leases fiber-optic networks and dark fiber to phone companies, wireless, Internet and other telecoms.

Dominion is one of the nation's largest producers and transporters of energy. Its portfolio includes 24,400 megawatts of generation, 12,200 miles of natural gas transmission and 6,490 miles of electric transmission lines.Market turmoil has stirred up the Big Cap 20. In the aftermath of "World Black Monday," how are the best-quality dividend payers on the S&P; 500 doing?
Not terribly bad, actually.

IBD wanted to see how many names within the 500 components of the key stock benchmark are flat or up for the year in price, produce a dividend yield of 1% or more, and showed profit growth in the latest quarter.
A total of 66 companies make the list.

What if you whittled the list down to those with a yield of 2.20% (matching the 500's yield) or greater? And you also required a minimum 10% EPS increase in the latest quarter and positive growth expected for the current fiscal year? The list shrinks to 14.
Here's a quick look at those elite large caps with exceptional earnings stability. On a scale of zero (most stable) to 99 (most volatile), they must score 25 or less.

GameStop (GME), the video game chain, shows a 3.3% annualized yield. The Grapevine, Texas, firm raised its payout twice since March 2014. The stock is trading just 7% off its 52-week high and up 30% year-to-date.

Valero Energy (VLO) is 19% off its 52-week peak, but still up 16% since Jan. 1. Full-year profit is seen up 25% to $8.27 a share. The yield is 2.7%. The three-year EPS Stability Factor is decent at 17.
This column profiled Leggett & Platt (LEG), which specializes in furniture internal mechanisms, in Monday's IBD.Reynolds American (RAI) has been featured 10 times in 2015.

Altria Group (MO) (5-year EPS Stability Factor 1, 4.3% yield), Eli Lilly (LLY) (5-year 9, 2.5%), Darden Restaurants (DRI) (3-year EPS Stability of 24, 3.3% yield), Equinix (EQIX) (3-year 25, 2.6%), Avery Dennison (AVY) (5-year 4, 2.6%), Essex Property Trust (ESS) (no EPS factor available, 2.7%), Carnival (CCL) (3-year 15, 2.6%), General Mills (GIS) (5-year 2, 3.2%), Public Storage (PSA) (no factor, 3.4%) and AvalonBay Communities (AVB) (no factor, 3.0%) also make the grade. LaSalle Hotel Properties (LHO) stock surged Monday as private equity giant Blackstone (BX) beat back a rival bid to buy the firm in a busy Monday for merger news.NextEra Energy (NEE), Fifth Third Bancorp (FITB), Roper Technologies (ROP) and IHS Markit (INFO) are other big names involved in takeovers and deals today.Blackstone won its battle for LaSalle Hotel Properties, paying $3.7 billion, or $33.50 per share.The private equity behemoth outdid the Pebblebrook Hotel Trust (PEB), which had tendered a $3.5 billion bid in April. LaSalle owns 41 upscale hotels, and operates in 11 markets in seven states and the District of Columbia.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. LaSalle stock rallied 5.4% to 33.62.The deal comes just days after Blackstone checked out of its position in Hilton Worldwide (HLT) after an 11-year stay by selling off the last of its shares. It sold off 15.8 million shares, around 5.8% of the iconic luxury hotel chain.Utility powerhouse NextEra Energy (NEE) revealed Monday that it will buy $5.08 billion in assets from rival Southern Co. (SO)NextEra will obtain Gulf Power, Florida City Gas and Southern's interests in the Oleander and Stanton natural-gas plants. The deal is worth $6.48 billion including debt.The move comes amid wider industry consolidation in the U.S. utilities look for ways to be more energy efficient. NextEra stock rose 2.4%. Southern advanced 1.7%.Fifth Third Bancorp will buy Chicago-based MB Financial Bank (MBFI) for $4.7 billion in a 90% stock, 10% cash deal.It will create the fourth-largest Chicago bank in total deposits. The combined firm will hold a 6.5% share of the total market in the city, and 20% of its middle market.Fifth Third fell 7.9%. MB Financial stock jumped 13%.The IT services provider announced Monday it is buying software company PowerPlan for $1.1 billion cash from private equity firm Thoma Bravo.It's the second billion-dollar deal between the companies. In 2016 Roper purchased business software business Deltek for $2.8 billion.Roper Technologies stock climbed 2.1%.Blackstone is involved in another deal Monday, selling its stake in data firm Ipreo to information services giant IHS Markit (INFO).Goldman Sachs (GS) is also selling of its stake in Ipreo as part of the $1.86 billion deal. The long-running bankruptcy saga of Energy Future Holdings is coming to a close now that Texas has approved the sale of the company's crown jewel.X The Texas Public Utility Commission authorized Sempra Energy's (SRE) $9.45 billion purchase of Oncor Electric Delivery, the state's largest utility, on Thursday. It was the last major step needed to end the almost four-year-old Energy Future bankruptcy, which rivaled Enron's as the largest ever for an energy company. A bankruptcy court approved Oncor's sale last month."It's the end of a long and twisting road," said Paul Patterson, a utility analyst for Glenrock Associates. "Sempra was able to prevail over several suitors."Hit by a collapse in natural gas prices, Energy Future was forced to sell Oncor, one of the most sought-after U.S. utilities, as it worked to restructure almost $50 billion in debt. Sempra beat out Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway (BRKA), NextEra Energy (NEE) and a group backed by Hunt Consolidated, which all tried and failed to buy the utility in recent years. Berkshire took a pretax loss of $837 million on a $2 billion Energy Future debt investment in 2013, and Buffett has called it "a big mistake," saying he wishes he'd never heard of the company."Sempra Energy is committed to being a good partner for the state and is supportive of Oncor's mission to provide Texans with safe, reliable and affordable electric service," said Debra L. Reed, chairwoman, president and CEO of Sempra Energy, who called the approval a "significant milestone."PUC Chairman DeAnn Walker thanked Sempra for agreeing to conditions that the agency required for an Oncor sale. Attendees at the meeting in Austin, Texas, broke out in applause as the three-member commission voted to approve the transaction after many failed attempts."It's so appropriate for a round of applause for all the work that has gone into this," Commissioner Brandy Marty Marquez said. "It's been enormous."Dallas-based Oncor offers steady, regulated returns in a state with a growing population and the highest electricity sales in the country. Oncor is Texas' largest transmission operator, managing about 134,000 miles (216,000 kilometers) of power lines that deliver electricity to about 10 million customers.Sempra runs power and gas utilities in Southern California, Chile and Peru that together serve more than 32 million consumers, according to the company's website. It also owns and operates almost 2,400 megawatts of renewable energy capacity with partners."They like Texas," Bloomberg Intelligence analyst Kit Konolige said of Sempra. "It's obviously the center of the energy industry."Before the bankruptcy, Energy Future was the target of the largest-ever leveraged buyout, when it was taken private for $48 billion in 2007 by a group led by KKR & Co. (KKR) and TPG Capital LP.Meanwhile, in commodity markets, West Texas Intermediate crude fell 1% to $60.53 a barrel. Gold dropped 0.4% to $1,320.68 an ounce.

Electricity provider Southern Co. said Monday it will buy natural gas distributor AGL Resources, creating the second-largest utility company in the U.S. based on the number of customers, behind only Exelon. Southern (SO) will pay $66 cash per AGL (GAS) share. The enterprise value of the deal is approximately $12 billion, according to the companies, including debt of $8 billion.…

Investors showed a little bit of fear about the prospects for four, and not three, quarter-point rate hikes following the first testimony to Congress by new Federal Reserve chief Jerome Powell, with stocks trading solidly lower heading into the final half hour.Powell said in prepared remarks that the U.S. central bank "will continue to strike a balance between avoiding an overheating economy and bringing ... price inflation to 2% on a sustained basis."Meanwhile, top growth stock Arista Networks (ANET) just edged lower Tuesday afternoon after retaking its key 50-day moving average on Monday. The software-centric data center networking gear specialist was down 0.2%, far better than the broader market.Arista, which reported stellar Q4 results a little more than a week ago (EPS up 64%, revenue up 43%, net margin of 29.3%, up 670 basis points vs. a year ago), needs to try to form a new base after triggering a sell signal Feb. 16. Shares are just 16% below an all-time high of 311.67, when the stock had a market cap of just over $23 billion.Arista has a reasonable float of 74 million shares, much smaller than the 4.77 billion share float of its arch rival Cisco Systems (CSCO). Cisco is having a super 2018 so far, up 18% year to date and rising more than 32% since clearing a shallow saucer with handle at 34.20 on Oct. 20.A saucer with handle has some of the aspects of a great cup with handle, but generally shows a more shallow look, even if the decline from high to low exceeds 30%. Plus, the large amount of time that it takes to form this winning stock chart pattern tends to wear investors out rather than shake them out.The Nasdaq composite eased 0.8%, giving back a chunk of its 2.9% advance over the prior two sessions. The tech-centered index was down as much as 1% earlier in the session. The Nasdaq 100 fell 0.9% as it experiences resistance near 7000 for the second time in nearly five weeks.The S&P 500 fell 0.8% while the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 0.7%. Strength in some industrial, tech and commodity-type components within the 30-stock Dow industrials helped blunt the decline.Homebuilders fell hard as the yield on the benchmark U.S. Treasury 10-year bond jumped back above the 2.90% level and bond prices halted a three-session win streak. Abengoa Yield (ABY) has created a cup-with-handle IPO base, 17% below its July high of 40.98 and 17% above its initial pricing at 29.

The London-based operation was formed by Spain's diversified engineering firm Abengoa (ABGB). It is a yieldco, somewhat similar to the U.S. master limited partnerships. MLPs are effectively holding companies for resource-based assets such as real estate or pipelines. They manage assets and offload surplus cash flow to investors in the form of a distribution or dividend.

A yieldco (also spelled as "YieldCo") houses assets that run on long-term operating contracts and tend to have predictable cash flows. Abengoa's focus on renewable electrical and water distribution utilities is right on target. Other yieldcos include NRG Energy (NRG), NextEra Energy (NEE) and SunEdison's (SUNE) Terraform Power (TERP).

More than half of Abengoa's facilities are in the U.S.; about a third are in South America, and the remainder in Europe. It developed and owns the Mojave Solar project, a 280-megawatt facility located north of Los Angeles. It owns another 280-MW site near Gila Bend, Ariz. Several more facilities are set to join the portfolio this year.
The Spanish parent held a 64% stake in Abengoa Yield at Dec. 11, according to Bloomberg. It planned to sell 10.6 million shares, but said it would not trim its stake below 51%.

Abengoa Yield went public in June, just as oil prices were starting their steep descent. The American depositary shares started their own descent in September, alongside other solar and alternative energy stocks that had been pumped up by oil prices hovering around $100 per barrel.
The tumble left IBD's alternative energy industry group ranked a weak No. 179 on Tuesday out of the total 197 groups.
RBC Capital Markets kept its outperform rating on the stock and, based on a strong backlog of projects and reduced risk outlook, raised the stock's price target to 45 from 37.

Analyst consensus sees Abengoa earning a nickel per share in 2014, up from a 4 cent loss in 2013. The 2015 consensus: $1.34 per share. RBC analyst Shelby Tucker projects the company's dividend yield will increase from 3.2% in 2014 to 5.7% in 2015 and 7.8% the year after.

Abengoa plans to report its Q4 results before the open on Feb. 25.
